snippet: Until now, the oldest fossil evidence for bilaterians dated back 555 million years. But now scientists have found fossil burrows of a segmented slug that are about 30 million years older.
abstract: Prof Murray K Gingras study in journal Science reports discovery of fossil burrows that belonged to a bilateral slug about 585 million years ago; fossils are about 30 million years older than the oldest known evidence of bilaterals, likely the first animals that could move on their own.
lead_paragraph: Until now, the oldest fossil evidence for bilaterians dated back 555 million years. But now scientists have found fossil burrows of a segmented slug that are about 30 million years older.

headline.print_headline: Slugs’ Tunnels Shed Light on Early Bilateral Animals
headline.seo: Slugs’ Tunnels Shed Light on Early Bilateral Animals
headline.main: Slugs’ Tunnels Shed Light on Early Bilateral Animals
